linesOfText.text: He was floating high up in the sky,
Quietly without a sound...
The wind was blowing slowly;
There was no one else around.
His name was Stormy Jr.,
And he'd drifted far from home.
The time had finally come for him
To set out on his own.
You see, Stormy was a rain cloud
Just like his mom and dad.
He hadn't seen them for a while,
And this made him very sad.
Sometimes he was lonely,
There just wasn't much to do,
As he sailed over snow-capped mountains
And oceans deep and blue.
But the one thing he loved most
And brought the greatest joy,
Was the wonderful sight and magical sounds
Of all the girls and boys.
Stormy was a friendly cloud.
He could hear and see for miles.
The joy in their laughter
And the beauty of their smiles.
But whenever he came closer
Wanting to watch them play,
He never understood
Why they always ran away.
That night Stormy was troubled,
Needing to talk with someone,
So he patiently awaited morning
To see his friend the Sun.
Morning came, he looked to the east
waiting for the Sun to rise,
Knowing his friend would have an answer
For he was old and wise.
When he saw the Sun he said
"Good morning,"
And the Sun asked "How are you?
"You don't seem happy, Stormy,
Is there something I can do"?
Stormy said," When I get close to children,
Their smiles turn to frowns
And then they run and hide from me;
They never want me around.
All of the children love you, Sun;
You have a special way
Of putting smiles on their faces
Each and every day."
He listened to Stormy's troubles
And after thinking for a while,
The Sun said " I know what you can do
But you must travel many miles."
There's a place out in the west
Where children hide from me,
It hardly ever rains there,
And is dry as dry can be.
I think that you should go there
And I'm sure that you will find
Some very special children,
Who I know will treat you kind.
So Stormy traveled to the west.
It sure was dry and hot !
But he didn't see any children;
Wasn't he in the right spot?
He let out a giant burst of rain
And, as it hit the ground,
The children came out from everywhere
And began to dance around.
They had smiles on their faces
And sparkles in their eyes;
Their hearts were full of love and care
As they reached up to the sky.
Stormy was filled with happiness;
He knew he'd found a home.
Each day he rained love on the children;
Never again would he be alone.
Stormy still lives in the west,
And it's true to this very day
That if you look up in the sky,
He'll be watching the children play.
THE END.
BY MATTHEW SCROGGINS.
